message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of darkening, blurring, and multiple dark streaks in the vision, along with smoking history, indicate the most likely diagnosis is vitreous hemorrhage. Central retinal vein and artery occlusions typically have sudden, painless, and complete loss of vision, while cataracts develop over a longer period of time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of multiple dark streaks and difficulty visualizing the fundus suggests vitreous hemorrhage. Central retinal artery occlusion would cause sudden and painless vision loss, but the patient reports blurring and darkening. Central retinal vein occlusion would cause painless vision loss and a visible fundus. Cataract would cause gradual visual impairment and is unlikely to present with sudden onset of dark streaks.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of blurring and darkening of vision, multiple dark streaks, and difficulty visualizing the fundus suggest a vitreous hemorrhage. Central retinal vein occlusion and central retinal artery occlusion usually do not cause such symptoms, and cataracts do not cause sudden vision changes. The patient's history of smoking and diabetes are risk factors for vitreous hemorrhage.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of sudden blurring and darkness of vision, accompanied by multiple dark streaks, suggest a vitreous hemorrhage. Central retinal vein occlusion might cause vision loss but doesn't have the sudden onset symptoms. Central retinal artery occlusion would cause sudden and complete unilateral loss of vision without accompanying symptoms. Cataract wouldn't cause sudden blurring and darkness of vision, and the fundus would be visible on examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of visual symptoms and difficulty visualizing the fundus suggest the most likely diagnosis is vitreous hemorrhage. Central retinal vein occlusion and central retinal artery occlusion would show different symptoms such as a sudden loss of vision rather than blurring and darkening. Cataract would not cause sudden vision changes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of blurred vision and darkening, along with the difficulty visualizing the fundus and diminished red reflex, suggest vitreous hemorrhage as the most likely diagnosis. Central retinal vein occlusion and central retinal artery occlusion would have sudden loss of vision but not blurred or darkened vision. Cataract would not cause sudden onset of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of blurred and darkened vision with multiple dark streaks suggests a vitreous hemorrhage. Central retinal vein occlusion or central retinal artery occlusion would have more profound visual deficits and no dark streaks. Cataract would not cause sudden onset vision changes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of blurring and darkening of vision suggest a vitreous hemorrhage, which can be caused by diabetic retinopathy or age-related macular degeneration. Central retinal vein or artery occlusion would cause sudden painless loss of vision, and cataracts would not cause sudden onset of symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset and dark streaks in vision suggest a potential vitreous hemorrhage. Central retinal vein occlusion may present with vision loss but it is not sudden and dark in appearance. Central retinal artery occlusion would present with sudden monocular vision loss but would not have dark streaks. Cataract would not present with sudden onset of vision loss and a diminished red reflex.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of dark streaks, reduced visual acuity, and difficulty in visualizing the fundus in the affected eye suggests a vitreous hemorrhage. Diabetes and smoking are risk factors for this condition. Central retinal vein and artery occlusions would show different findings on ophthalmologic examination, and cataracts typically present with a slow onset of visual changes.
